Award.AwardTitle: Physical Chemistry of Macromolecules as Probed by High Resolution Solid State NMR
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Chemistry Division supports Professor Kurt Zilm of Yale University to develop new nuclear magnetic resonance methods for investigation of the chemistry, dynamics and structures of biomolecules. The research will use relaxation methods to identify how structure is related to the dispersion in internal protein and water motions, and to obtain distances in biologically relevant macromolecular complexes. To extend solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance to more complex and size limited samples, new instruments will be developed with 1 to 2 orders of magnitude higher specific sensitivity. These will combine paramagnetic condensed acquisition with very fast cryogenic magic angle sample spinning, as well as microliter sample size dynamic nuclear polarization hardware. When developed, these capabilities will be applied to characterize mutant visual pigments and functionally distinct isoforms of prion protein oligomers. Currently, these are samples where obtaining nuclear magnetic resonance data is impractical on sub-microliter samples.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a well-known diagnostic tool in medicine that uses nuclear spin information, often in water, to distinguish different types of tissue in the body. The study of nuclear spin properties of water in proteins is directly related to understanding and improving contrast in MRI technology. This research involves fundamental studies of the distribution of water in proteins, knowledge from which will help improve the sensitivity and the spatial resolution of MRI experiments. The research program also encourages under-represented minorities to enter science careers through involvement in the public education program "Science on Saturdays," a series of scientific lectures and hands-on demonstrations attended by up to 300 members of the public at a time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the physical chemistry of macromolecular systems is central to understanding the chemistry of life. Nuclear magnetic resonance or NMR spectroscopy is a method for imaging the atomic details of macromolecular structure and for following the dynamical behavior of large macromolecular complexes. The advantages of solid state NMR are its exquisite resolution, and the ability to observe spectroscopic signals that are specific to single atoms in single amino acids in large proteins. Solid state NMR makes it possible to obtain structures of large macromolecular complexes and to follow their chemistry spectroscopically with more detail than any other analytical technique.

Unfortunately the high resolution if NMR comes with a cost, and that is inherently low detection sensitivity. In this grant one of the principal thrusts of the research program was to develop instrumentation with enhanced NMR sensitivity. These developments included innovations in microliter dynamic nuclear polarization hardware, pulsed field gradients for solids NMR, and fast magic angle spinning at cryogenic temperatures. Dynamic nuclear polarization or DNP is a method to enhance NMR spectra.  A stable free radical polarizing agent is added to the NMR samples, and then the electron spins are irradiated with microwaves. Through cross relaxation the nuclear spin polarization is enhanced, leading to a very much larger NMR signal.  A significant hurdle to overcome is the efficient penetration of the NMR sample by the microwave field. In this grant methods were developed to obtain much higher microwave magnetic fields within the NMR sample by innovative NMR coil design and through novel dielectric antenna devices. In this manner enhancements of over 400-fold for the C-13 spectra of synthetic diamonds were achieved using a low power diode microwave source, exceeding those obtained with a high power gyrotron. Since diode sources are more than 10 times less expensive than gyrotrons, this makes DNP accessible to many more laboratories. Some of these advances are being commercialized now via an SBIR award in collaboration with two companies, Phoenix NMR and Bridge12 Technologies. High field electron spin resonance using a frequency swept quasi-optical approach was also developed as a way to quantitatively characterize the microwave field efficiency of DNP NMR probes.

Other work supported in the grant investigated the use of pulsed field gradients in MAS NMR to speed data acquisition, application of solids NMR to elucidate the physical chemistry of a gel phase formed by prion protein and oligomers of amyloid-beta peptide, and the development of a miniature device equipped with a nano-filtration membrane to allow pH or ionic strength of solid samples for NMR to be varied in situ in the NMR sample cell by centrifugation. Methods were also developed using relaxation phenomena to better systematically study molecular motion in macromolecular complexes by solid state NMR.

In addition this grant activity supports a public science education program, Science Saturdays, organized by the PI. Six lectures, 3 per semester, are given by Yale faculty to the public on Saturday mornings. Two hours of hands on demonstrations precede each lecture. Attendance is typically between 150 and 300 members of the public. The program is part of Yale Pathways to Science, and heavily advertised to middle and high school students. A website is maintained with YouTube videos of all lectures, and can be viewed at http://onhsa.yale.edu/science-saturdays.
